title: TESCO | SDE2 | Bengaluru
content:
Education: B. Tech
Years of Experience: 5
Date of the Offer: April 2024
Company: Tesco
Title/Level: SDE-II
Location: Bangalore
Salary: 4500000 (Fixed including PF)
Signing Bonus: N/A
Stock bonus: N/A
Bonus: N/A
Total comp (Salary + Bonus + Stock): ~45LPA


Current:
US based startup: 32LPA Fixed + 3 lakh variable - Laid Off in March
No other offer in hand, Recruiter kind of screwed me with their "strict 30% only hike" policy. they mentioned that any other kind of hike is based on business criticality and internal team parity. I couldn't negotiate a lot since I was laid off and getting an offer was of top priority. I was also forced to join the company immediately. 
it turns out me joining the team was highly critical as well. I hate how recruiters act like it's coming out of their pocket! apologies about the rant. I hope if you are negotiating with a tesco recruiter make sure you hold your ground because they have got a lot to offer

title: Microsoft | SDE - II | Noida | Offer
content:

title: Newrelic | SSE | HYD
content:
Education: Btech in ECE
Years of Experience: 6
Current Compensation: 40 L CTC
Prior Experience: e-commerce

Date of the Offer: April 20124
Company: Newrelic
Title/Level: SSE
Location: HYD
Salary: Rs. 50 L
Relocation: Rs. 1 L
Retention Bonus: Rs. 2.5 L
Stock bonus: 0
Bonus: 6% performance bonus (paid quarterly from next year)
Total comp (Salary + Bonus + Stock): ~Rs. 52.5 L
Benefits: Nothing
Other details: Offer was given within a week, they said this is the best offer for my role and YOE.
Notice period: 2 months
Probationay period: 3 months

Good: Tech is pretty strong, a lot of learning but not sure of management and pressure. It's purely a tech company.
Bad: Newrelic fired last year in the US and now they are expanding teams in India.
Neutral: they went from public to private.

FYI: New Relic is one of the world's largest consumers of Kafka. New Relic's Kafka installation processes around 125 petabytes of data each month, or about three billion data points per minute. New Relic has been using Apache Kafka for over 10 years to power its large streaming platform, which ingests and processes observability data
